title.narrative: Making Women Access to Land & property

description.narrative:
Overall objective To strengthen the WLRM to promote women’s land rights in Uganda.
Specific Objectives; 1. To build the capacity of the WLRM on movement building, transformative leadership, feminism, grassroots organizing and sustainability 2. To provide a platform for consensus building, joint advocacy, accountability and amplification of voices for women’s land rights
Outcomes 1. Capacity of the WLRM strengthened 2. Platform created for women to voice their issues 3. Increased awareness of the legal and policy frameworks on WLRs.
Planned Activities 1. Training of grassroots women leaders and members of their organizations on transformative leadership for women’s land and natural resource rights is carried out. 2. Training CSO(Women Land rights Movement) on gender and power relations training 3. Undertake campaigns led by grassroots and indigenous women to secure land rights are linked with global campaigns addressing land inequality, land rights of indigenous communities and climatechange. 4. Organize platforms for grassroots women to amplify their voice and participate in key decision-making spaces, such as the CEDAW in side-events or related activities alongside these spaces.

participating-org.narrative: LANDnet Uganda was conceived in 2012 by the founding director Esther Obaikol in the after math of the land grabs campaign in Uganda, a campaign that saw the recognition of the centrality of land for investment to national development. The foundation of LANDnet lies in the principles of equity and equality, in the desire to ensure inclusion and equal opportunities in access to and control overproductive resources including land. Land is a cultural issue in Uganda with cultural diversity in gender relations and property rights. Approaches for strengthening women#s land rights must therefore be tailored to local circumstances and not just replicated from one place to another. LANDnet#s valve proposition is to go beyond the rhetoric of gender mainstreaming and develop together with its stakeholders the gender foot print the marks how within the land sector there is progressive reduction in gender inequality both in the function of land governance and in the practice of tenure security Through effectiveparticipation of all stakeholders, LANDnet aligns itself to existing global frameworks such as the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible governance of Tenure of Land, Forests and Fisheries (VGGT) and Africa Framework <(>&<)> Guidelines on Land Policies in Africa. LANDnet along with dedicated support from External experts will strive to achieve the global frameworks.

description.narrative: Increased equality & equity in formal rules and practices as laid down in constitutions, laws, and policies of governments
cases where government policies and legislation are increasingly promoting equality and equity
cases where government practices are increasingly participatory and accountable
